title: Lab 1: R and RStudio Installation
text:
Introduction
To perform data science at DCC, we use two primary tools. Think of R as the ‚Äúengine‚Äù of a car and RStudio as the ‚Äúdashboard.‚Äù You need the engine to go, but you need the dashboard to steer and see where you are going.

If you are using a DCC Chromebook or a computer where you cannot install software, please contact the instructor about using Posit Cloud (the web-based version of RStudio).

title: Lab 1: R and RStudio Installation
text:
Step 1: Install R (The Engine)
You must install R before you install RStudio.

Go to the CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network) website.
Select the download link for your operating system:

Download R for Windows -> Click ‚Äúbase‚Äù -> Click ‚ÄúDownload R 4.x.x for Windows.‚Äù
Download R for (macOS) -> Download the .pkg file that matches your chip (Apple silicon M1/M2 or Intel).

Run the downloaded installer and keep all default settings by clicking ‚ÄúNext‚Äù or ‚ÄúContinue.‚Äù

title: Lab 1: R and RStudio Installation
text:
Step 2: Install RStudio (The Dashboard)
RStudio is the interface where you will write your code and view your data visualizations.

Visit the Posit Download Page.
Scroll down to ‚Äú2: Install RStudio‚Äù and click the button for your operating system.
Run the installer. Like R, it is best to keep all default settings.

title: Lab 1: R and RStudio Installation
text:
Step 3: Verify Your Setup
Let‚Äôs make sure the ‚Äúengine‚Äù and ‚Äúdashboard‚Äù are talking to each other.

Open RStudio from your applications folder or start menu.
Find the Console pane (usually on the bottom left).
Type the following code and press Enter:


print("Hello, MAT 186!")

[1] "Hello, MAT 186!"








Importantüìù Lab Task 2: Capturing Your Work



Follow these steps to take a screenshot of your R console:

Run the Code: In your Console (the bottom-left panel of RStudio), type the following exactly and press Enter: print("Hello, MAT 186!")
Take a Screenshot: Capture an image of your screen showing that message.

Windows: Use Windows Key + Shift + S.
Mac: Use Cmd + Shift + 4.

Save Your Work: Save the screenshot into your Mat186 folder on your computer. Give it a clear name like Lab2_Screenshot.
Submit: Upload this image file to the Lab 2 assignment folder in your course portal.

title: Lab 1: R and RStudio Installation
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lab, students will be able to:

Successfully install the R programming language.
Install the RStudio Desktop Integrated Development Environment (IDE).
Verify the installation by running a simple command.

title: Lab 5: Getting Data into R
text:
By the end of this lab, students will be able to:

Understand the difference between Absolute and Relative file paths.
Import data from a local CSV file.
Import data directly from a URL (Web).
Use the readr package (part of the tidyverse).





Before we can visualize or model data, we have to ‚Äúimport‚Äù it into R‚Äôs memory. Most data you will encounter is stored in CSV (Comma Separated Values) format, which looks like an Excel spreadsheet but is much lighter and easier for programs to read.




R needs to know which folder on your computer it should ‚Äúlook‚Äù in.

Crucial Step: This is why we use RStudio Projects (from Lab 2). When you open your .Rproj file, R automatically sets your folder as the ‚ÄúWorking Directory.‚Äù

To check where R is looking,

Locate the Console pane (typically in the bottom-left of RStudio).
Type getwd() at the command prompt (>). It is important to include the parentheses () because it is a function.
Press the Enter (or Return) key on your keyboard.





The easiest way to get started is to pull data directly from the internet. We will use the read_csv() function from the tidyverse.






Noteüí° Tip: Working with Code Chunks



To Insert a New Chunk: Click the green ‚Äú+C‚Äù icon (Insert) in the toolbar at the top of your editor script, then select R. This creates a new gray box for your code.
To Run the Code: Click the green ‚ÄúPlay‚Äù button (the small triangle) in the top-right corner of the gray box. The results will appear directly below the chunk in your document.




In this step, we will tell R to go to the internet, find our dataset, and bring it into RStudio so we can analyze it.
Follow these steps: 1. Create a new R chunk in your RStudio document. 2. Copy the code below by clicking the copy icon in the top-right corner of the gray box. 3. Paste the code into your new chunk in RStudio. 4. Click the Green Play button (the triangle) to run the code.

# Step 1: Load the tidyverse tools
library(tidyverse)

# Step 2: Set the web address for the Low Birth Weight (LBW) data
url <- "https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/COUNT/lbw.csv"

# Step 3: Download the data and name it 'lbw_data'
lbw_data <- read_csv(url)

# Step 4: Show the first few rows of the data
head(lbw_data)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 11
  rownames   low smoke  race   age   lwt   ptl    ht    ui   ftv   bwt
     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1        1     0     0     2    19   182     0     0     1     0  2523
2        2     0     0     3    33   155     0     0     0     3  2551
3        3     0     1     1    20   105     0     0     0     1  2557
4        4     0     1     1    21   108     0     0     1     2  2594
5        5     0     1     1    18   107     0     0     1     0  2600
6        6     0     0     3    21   124     0     0     0     0  2622








Tip‚úÖ Success Check



If the code worked, you should see a table appear directly below your code chunk starting with column names like rownames, low, age, and lwt.







Often, you will download a dataset from a site like Kaggle or a government portal.This link to free data

Find a CSV file (or download a sample one).
Move that file into your MAT186_Labs folder.
Use the following code (replace filename.csv with your actual file name):

my_data <- read_csv("filename.csv")





‚ÄúFile not found‚Äù: This usually means the file is not in your Project folder, or you misspelled the name (remember: Data.csv is different from data.csv).
Column Parsing: Sometimes R guesses the data type wrong (e.g., thinking a zip code is a number instead of a label). We will learn to fix this in future labs!



Lab Task 5:

Find any public CSV dataset. For example, this link to free data. Use the lbw data set.







Tipüì• How to Download the Data



Follow these steps to save the dataset to your computer:

Search for the Data: In the search box at the top of the website, type ‚Äúlbw‚Äù.
Download the File: Find the link labeled CSV.

Right-click (or Ctrl+click on a Mac) the CSV link.
Select ‚ÄúSave Link As‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúDownload Linked File As‚Ä¶‚Äù.

Save it in the Right Place: Save the file directly into your Mat186 folder on your computer.




Import it into a new Quarto document using read_csv.
Use the glimpse() command to show the structure of your data:

glimpse(my_data)

Render the document and confirm that your data table appears in the HTML.

title: Lab 6: Data Collection and Sources
text:
Distinguish between Primary and Secondary data.
Explore ‚ÄúOpen Data‚Äù portals (Local, State, and Federal).
Understand the concept of Tidy Data.
Practice ethical data attribution.





Data doesn‚Äôt just appear out of nowhere; it is collected via sensors, surveys, web scraping, or manual entry. As a data scientist at DCC, you should know how to find reliable sources of information to answer real-world questions.




Government agencies often provide ‚ÄúOpen Data‚Äù portals where anyone can download datasets for free. These are excellent sources for your final projects.



Dutchess County Open Data: Local data on parcels, transit, and public safety.
NY State Open Data: Information on education, health, and the environment across New York.
U.S. Census Bureau: The gold standard for demographic data in the United States.






Once you collect data, it needs to be in a specific format for R to read it easily. This is called Tidy Data. There are three rules:

Each variable must have its own column.
Each observation (case) must have its own row.
Each value must have its own cell.





Whenever you collect data that you didn‚Äôt create yourself, you must provide a Data Citation. This gives credit to the original collectors and allows others to verify your work.
A good citation includes:

The name of the organization.
The year the data was accessed.
The URL/Link to the dataset.



Lab Task 6: The Scavenger Hunt

Visit the NY State Open Data Portal.
Search for a dataset that interests you (e.g., ‚ÄúStudent Enrollment‚Äù or ‚ÄúWater Quality‚Äù).
Download the CSV version of that data.
Move the file into your RStudio Project folder.
In a new Quarto document, write a short paragraph describing:

Where the data came from.
Who collected it.
What one row in the dataset represents (the observation).

Use read_csv() to load the data and show the first 10 rows using head().






Data you find ‚Äúin the wild‚Äù is rarely perfect. In the next lab, we will learn how to ‚Äúclean‚Äù the data you just found‚Äîremoving empty rows and fixing typos!

title: Lab 7: Cleaning Data with dplyr
text:
Understand the concept of ‚ÄúData Wrangling.‚Äù
Use the Pipe Operator (|>) to chain commands.
Learn core cleaning functions: filter(), select(), and rename().
Handle missing values (NA).





‚ÄúRaw‚Äù data is rarely ready for analysis. It might have columns you don‚Äôt need, rows that aren‚Äôt relevant to your study, or names that are hard to type. In this lab, we use the dplyr package (part of the tidyverse) to ‚Äútidy up‚Äù our datasets.




Think of the pipe operator as saying the words ‚Äúand then.‚Äù It takes the output of one function and passes it to the next.
Instead of writing: clean_data <- filter(raw_data, age > 18)
We write: clean_data <- raw_data |> filter(age > 18)






If your dataset has 100 columns but you only need 3, use select().

library(tidyverse)

# Keep only the 'name' and 'height' columns
sw_small <- starwars |> 
  select(name, height)

# Use knitr::kable to generate an accessible HTML table
knitr::kable(head(sw_small))



Table¬†1: Table 1: Name and height of the first six characters in the Star Wars dataset.

If you only want to look at specific observations (e.g., characters taller than 100cm).

library(tidyverse)

# Keep only rows where height is greater than 100
tall_characters <- starwars |> 
  filter(height > 100) |>
  select(name, height, species, homeworld) # Selecting specific columns makes tables easier to read

# Use kable to create an accessible HTML table structure
knitr::kable(head(tall_characters))

If a column name is confusing or has spaces, rename it.

library(tidyverse)

# Change 'homeworld' to 'home_planet'
sw_clean <- starwars |> 
  rename(home_planet = homeworld)

# We select a few columns so the table isn't too wide for a screen reader
knitr::kable(head(sw_clean[, c("name", "height", "home_planet")]))

In R, missing values are represented as NA (Not Available). You can‚Äôt calculate the mean of a column if it has NA values without telling R what to do.
To remove rows with any missing data:

library(tidyverse)

# Remove rows where height is NA
tidy_sw <- starwars |> 
  drop_na(height)

# Display the first six rows using an accessible HTML table format
knitr::kable(head(tidy_sw[, c("name", "height", "mass", "species")]))

Open your Quarto document from Lab 6 (the one with your NY State Open Data).
Create a new section called ‚ÄúData Cleaning.‚Äù
Use select() to keep only the 4 most important columns in your dataset.
Use filter() to narrow your data down to one specific category or a certain range of numbers.
Use rename() to make at least one column name easier to read.
Render your document and check that your new ‚ÄúCleaned‚Äù table looks correct.






Always run glimpse(your_data) after cleaning to make sure you haven‚Äôt accidentally deleted something you meant to keep!

title: Lab 8: Data Exploration and Visualization with ggplot2
text:
Calculate ‚ÄúSummary Statistics‚Äù using dplyr.
Understand the Grammar of Graphics (Data, Aesthetics, and Geoms).
Create distributions (Histograms) and relationships (Scatter Plots).
Identify outliers and patterns through visual-first discovery.





Before we draw, we must understand the ‚Äúcenter‚Äù and ‚Äúspread‚Äù of our data. We use summarize() to get the hard numbers.

library(tidyverse)

# Analyzing the Star Wars dataset
starwars |>
  drop_na(height) |>
  summarize(
    mean_height = mean(height),
    median_height = median(height),
    sd_height = sd(height)
  ) |>
  knitr::kable()



Table¬†1: Summary statistics for Star Wars character heights, including mean, median, and standard deviation (measured in cm).






mean_height
median_height
sd_height




174.6049
180
34.77416












In ggplot2, every plot has three essential ingredients:

Data: The dataframe we are using.
Aesthetics (aes): The mapping of data to the axes (x and y).
Geoms: The geometric shapes used to represent the data (points, bars, lines).





A histogram helps us see where the data is ‚Äúclumped.‚Äù If the mean and median are very different, the histogram will show a ‚Äúskew.‚Äù

library(tidyverse)

ggplot(data = starwars, mapping = aes(x = height)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 15, fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Character Heights",
    x = "Height (cm)",
    y = "Frequency"
  )







Figure¬†1: Histogram showing the distribution of Star Wars character heights.









To see if two numeric variables are related (like height and weight), we use geom_point().

# Removing the extreme outlier (Jabba the Hutt) for a better view
starwars_filtered <- starwars |> filter(mass < 500)

ggplot(data = starwars_filtered, mapping = aes(x = height, y = mass)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkgreen", alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +

       x = "Height (cm)",
       y = "Mass (kg)")

  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightgray") +

    x = "Gender Identity",
    y = "Height (cm)"

title: Lab 9: Probability and Sampling Distributions
text:
Distinguish between Discrete and Continuous probability distributions.
Visualize the Normal Distribution (the ‚ÄúBell Curve‚Äù).
Demonstrate the Central Limit Theorem through simulation.
Understand how sample size affects the ‚ÄúStandard Error.‚Äù





In nature and data science, many variables (like heights or exam scores) follow a ‚ÄúNormal‚Äù distribution. We can use R to visualize the perfect mathematical curve and compare it to our real data.

library(tidyverse)

# Generating a theoretical normal distribution
data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)) |>
  ggplot(aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm, color = "blue", linewidth = 1) +
  labs(title = "The Standard Normal Distribution (z-distribution)",
       subtitle = "Mean = 0, SD = 1",
       x = "Standard Deviations", y = "Density")







Figure¬†1: The Standard Normal Distribution curve with a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1.









When we have ‚ÄúYes/No‚Äù outcomes (like a coin flip or a student passing a test), we use the Binomial Distribution.

library(tidyverse)

# Simulating 100 people flipping a coin 10 times each
set.seed(123) # Setting a seed makes the simulation (and your alt-text) consistent
flips <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.5)

ggplot(data.frame(flips), aes(x = flips)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "darkorange", color = "white") +
  labs(title = "Binomial Distribution of Coin Flips",
       x = "Number of Heads", 
       y = "Frequency")







Figure¬†2: Bar chart showing the results of 100 people flipping a coin 10 times each.









The CLT is the ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù of statistics. It states that if you take enough samples, the distribution of the sample means will always look normal, even if the original data is messy or skewed.



library(tidyverse)

# 1. Take 1000 samples of size 30 from a random population
# We set a seed so the 'bell shape' described in alt-text stays consistent
set.seed(42)
samples <- replicate(1000, mean(rexp(30, rate = 0.5)))

# 2. Visualize the results
ggplot(data.frame(samples), aes(x = samples)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "seagreen", color = "white", bins = 30) +
  labs(title = "Sampling Distribution of the Mean",
       subtitle = "Notice the bell shape! This is the Central Limit Theorem in action.",
       x = "Sample Means", y = "Count")







Figure¬†3: Sampling distribution of the mean for 1,000 samples (n = 30) drawn from an exponential population.










We can use the pnorm() function to calculate the probability of a specific event occurring.
Example: If the average height of a character is 170cm with an SD of 10, what is the probability of a character being taller than 190cm?

# Probability of a height greater than 190cm
prob <- 1 - pnorm(190, mean = 170, sd = 10)



Lab Task 9:

Create a new Quarto document titled ‚ÄúLab 9: Probability.‚Äù
Create a histogram of a variable from your own dataset. Does it look ‚ÄúNormal‚Äù?
Use mean() and sd() to find the center and spread of that variable.
The Simulation: Use the ‚ÄúCLT simulation‚Äù code above, but change the sample size from 30 to 5. Render it. Then change it to 100 and render it again.
Observation: Write 2 sentences explaining how the ‚Äúspread‚Äù of the histogram changed when you increased the sample size.

title: Lab 10: Statistical Inference for One Mean
text:
Understand the logic of Null (\(H_0\)) and Alternative (\(H_a\)) Hypotheses.
Calculate and interpret Confidence Intervals.
Conduct a One-Sample t-test in R.
Interpret the p-value to make a statistical decision.





We rarely have data for an entire population (like every person in New York). Instead, we use a Sample to make an educated guess about the Population.

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): The status quo. There is ‚Äúnothing going on‚Äù or no difference.
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): What we are trying to prove. There is a significant difference.





A confidence interval gives us a range of plausible values for the true population mean. We usually use a 95% Confidence Level.

library(tidyverse)

# Let's look at the average height of Star Wars characters
starwars_heights <- starwars |> drop_na(height)

# Running the t-test
test_results <- t.test(starwars_heights$height, conf.level = 0.95)

# Converting the test result list into an accessible table
library(broom)
tidy_results <- tidy(test_results)

knitr::kable(
  tidy_results[, c("estimate", "conf.low", "conf.high")],
  col.names = c("Mean Height (cm)", "Lower Bound (2.5%)", "Upper Bound (97.5%)"),
  digits = 2
)



Table¬†1: 95% Confidence Interval for the mean height of Star Wars characters.






Mean Height (cm)
Lower Bound (2.5%)
Upper Bound (97.5%)




174.6
166.92
182.29












Imagine a claim that the ‚ÄúAverage height of a galactic citizen is 175 cm.‚Äù Does our data support this?

# 1. Perform the test
t_test_results <- t.test(starwars_heights$height, mu = 175)

# 2. Use the 'broom' library to turn the text output into a data frame
library(broom)
tidy_t <- tidy(t_test_results)

# 3. Create an accessible table with descriptive headers
knitr::kable(
  tidy_t[, c("statistic", "p.value", "estimate", "conf.low", "conf.high")],
  col.names = c("t-statistic", "p-value", "Sample Mean", "95% CI Lower", "95% CI Upper"),
  digits = 4
)



Table¬†2: One-sample t-test results comparing Star Wars character heights to a null hypothesis mean of 175 cm.






t-statistic
p-value
Sample Mean
95% CI Lower
95% CI Upper




-0.1022
0.9188
174.6049
166.9157
182.2941











t: The test statistic (how many standard errors we are from the claim).
df: Degrees of freedom (sample size minus 1).
p-value: The probability that we would see our result if the Null Hypothesis were true.






In MAT 186, we typically use an alpha (\(\alpha\)) level of 0.05.

If p-value < 0.05: We Reject the Null Hypothesis. The result is ‚ÄúStatistically Significant.‚Äù
If p-value > 0.05: We Fail to Reject the Null Hypothesis. We do not have enough evidence to support the change.



Lab Task 10:

Use your personal dataset from previous labs.
Pick a numeric variable (e.g., age, price, or score).
State your Hypotheses: * \(H_0: \mu = \text{choose a number close to your average}\)

\(H_a: \mu \neq \text{that same number}\)

Run a t.test() in R using your variable and your chosen mu.
The Conclusion: In your Quarto document, write a formal conclusion. ‚ÄúSince the p-value was [insert p-value], we [reject/fail to reject] the null hypothesis. There [is/is not] sufficient evidence to suggest the mean is different from [insert mu].‚Äù






When writing your report, always include the Confidence Interval. This helps readers (and screen readers) understand the magnitude of your finding, not just whether it was ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù or not.

title: Lab 11: Statistical Inference for One Proportion
text:
Understand the conditions for the Large Sample Proportions Test.
State Null (\(H_0\)) and Alternative (\(H_a\)) hypotheses for proportions.
Use prop.test() in R to calculate p-values and confidence intervals.
Apply these skills to real-world categorical data.





A proportion (\(p\)) is the ratio of ‚Äúsuccesses‚Äù to the total number of trials. * Example: If 45 out of 100 students at DCC use RStudio, the sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\)) is \(0.45\) (or 45%).




When we test a proportion, we are comparing our sample to a claimed population value (\(p_0\)).

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): \(p = p_0\) (The proportion is exactly what was claimed).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): \(p \neq p_0\) (The proportion is different than the claim).





We use the prop.test() function. You need two numbers: x (number of successes) and n (total sample size).
Scenario: A news report claims that 50% of Star Wars characters are Humans. In our dataset, we find that 35 out of 87 characters are Human. Is the report‚Äôs 50% claim accurate?

# 1. Perform the test
prop_results <- prop.test(x = 35, n = 87, p = 0.50, correct = FALSE)

# 2. Tidy the result into a data frame
library(broom)
tidy_prop <- tidy(prop_results)

# 3. Create an accessible table with descriptive headers
knitr::kable(
  tidy_prop[, c("estimate", "statistic", "p.value", "conf.low", "conf.high")],
  col.names = c("Sample Proportion", "Chi-squared", "p-value", "Lower 95% CI", "Upper 95% CI"),
  digits = 4
)



Table¬†1: One-sample proportion test results comparing the observed proportion of humans (35/87) to a null hypothesis of 0.50.






Sample Proportion
Chi-squared
p-value
Lower 95% CI
Upper 95% CI




0.4023
3.3218
0.0684
0.3055
0.5074











X-squared: The test statistic (similar to the \(t\) value from Lab 10).
p-value: If this is below 0.05, we reject the claim that the true proportion is 50%.
sample estimate: This is your \(\hat{p}\) (the \(35/87\) from your data).






The prop.test() also gives you a 95% Confidence Interval. This tells you the range where the true population proportion likely falls.
If your confidence interval is (0.301, 0.508), it means we are 95% confident that the true percentage of Humans in the galaxy is between 30.1% and 50.8%.


Lab Task 11:

Pick a categorical variable from your dataset (e.g., Gender, Species, or Success/Failure).
Count how many ‚Äúsuccesses‚Äù (a specific category) you have compared to the total.
The Test: Test a claim of your choice. (e.g., ‚ÄúIs the proportion of [category] equal to 0.25?‚Äù)
Run prop.test() in your Quarto document.
Report: * What was your sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\))?

Was your p-value significant?
What is the 95% confidence interval for your proportion?







When reporting proportions to a general audience, always convert decimals to percentages and round to one decimal place (e.g., \(0.4022\) becomes 40.2%). This makes your findings much easier to digest for readers using assistive technology.

title: Lab 12: Statistical Inference for Two Means
text:
Understand the difference between Independent and Paired samples.
State the Null (\(H_0\)) and Alternative (\(H_a\)) hypotheses for comparing two groups.
Conduct an Independent Samples t-test in R.
Visualize the difference between groups using Boxplots.





We use an Independent Samples t-test when we want to compare the means of two distinct, unrelated groups. * Example: Do ‚ÄúHumans‚Äù have a different average height than ‚ÄúDroids‚Äù? * Example: Is the average house price in Poughkeepsie different from the average price in Fishkill?




In this test, we are looking at the difference between the two population means (\(\mu_1 - \mu_2\)).

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) (The means are the same; the difference is zero).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): \(\mu_1 \neq \mu_2\) (The means are significantly different).





Before running the math, we should always visualize the two groups side-by-side using a Boxplot.

library(tidyverse)

# Comparing heights of Humans and Droids
comparison_data <- starwars |> 
  filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid")) |>
  drop_na(height)

ggplot(comparison_data, aes(x = species, y = height, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") + # Better color contrast for accessibility
  labs(title = "Height Comparison: Humans vs. Droids",
       x = "Species",
       y = "Height (cm)")







Figure¬†1: Comparison of height distributions between Humans and Droids.









In R, we use the ‚Äúformula‚Äù syntax: y ~ x (where y is the numeric value and x is the grouping category).

# 1. Conduct the Independent Samples t-test
t_test_results <- t.test(height ~ species, data = comparison_data)

# 2. Tidy the results into a data frame
library(broom)
tidy_t_test <- tidy(t_test_results)

# 3. Create an accessible table with descriptive headers
knitr::kable(
  tidy_t_test[, c("estimate", "statistic", "p.value", "conf.low", "conf.high")],
  col.names = c("Difference in Means", "t-statistic", "p-value", "Lower 95% CI", "Upper 95% CI"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†1: Independent samples t-test comparing the mean heights of Humans and Droids.






Difference in Means
t-statistic
p-value
Lower 95% CI
Upper 95% CI




-46.8
-2.119
0.1
-107.658
14.058











p-value: If p < 0.05, we conclude that the average heights of Humans and Droids are significantly different.
95% Confidence Interval: This gives the range of the difference between the two means. If the interval contains 0, the results are usually not significant.

title: Lab 13: Statistical Inference for Two Proportions
text:
Compare the ‚Äúsuccess rates‚Äù or percentages of two independent groups.
State the Null (\(H_0\)) and Alternative (\(H_a\)) hypotheses for differences in proportions.
Use the prop.test() function in R for two-sample comparisons.
Create a Stacked Bar Chart to visualize the relative differences between groups.





In Lab 11, we looked at one proportion. In the real world, we usually want to compare two. For example: * Does Group A have a higher graduation rate than Group B? * Is a medicine more effective in the treatment group than the control group?




We are testing the difference between two population proportions (\(p_1 - p_2\)).

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): \(p_1 = p_2\) (There is no difference between the groups).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): \(p_1 \neq p_2\) (The groups have significantly different proportions).





When comparing proportions, a standard bar chart can be misleading if the group sizes are different. We use position = "fill" to show the percentage (0 to 100%) rather than the raw count.
library(tidyverse)

# Comparing 'Success' across two different categories
ggplot(my_data, aes(x = group_variable, fill = success_variable)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill") +
  labs(title = "Proportional Comparison of Success by Group",
       y = "Proportion (0 to 1)",
       x = "Group Name")

library(tidyverse)

# Creating a simplified category: Tatooine vs Other
starwars_props <- starwars |>
  filter(!is.na(gender)) |>
  mutate(location = if_else(homeworld == "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Other"))

ggplot(starwars_props, aes(x = location, fill = gender)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill") +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "mako") + # High contrast, color-blind friendly palette
  labs(title = "Gender Proportions: Tatooine vs. Other Worlds",
       subtitle = "Standardized to 100% using position = 'fill'",
       x = "Homeworld Category",
       y = "Proportion",
       fill = "Gender")







Figure¬†1: Stacked bar chart showing the proportion of gender identities for characters from Tatooine versus other homeworlds.









In R, we provide the ‚Äúsuccesses‚Äù and the ‚Äútotals‚Äù as vectors within the prop.test() function.
Scenario: * Group 1: 45 people out of 100 succeeded. * Group 2: 30 people out of 100 succeeded.

# 1. Perform the test
# x = number of successes (45 and 30)
# n = total sample sizes (100 and 100)
results <- prop.test(x = c(45, 30), n = c(100, 100), correct = FALSE)

# 2. Tidy the results into a data frame
library(broom)
tidy_prop_two <- tidy(results)

# 3. Create an accessible table with descriptive headers
# Note: 'estimate' in a two-sample test contains the proportions for both groups
knitr::kable(
  tidy_prop_two[, c("statistic", "p.value", "conf.low", "conf.high")],
  col.names = c("Chi-squared", "p-value", "Lower 95% CI", "Upper 95% CI"),
  digits = 4
)



Table¬†1: Two-sample proportion test comparing Group 1 (45/100) and Group 2 (30/100).






Chi-squared
p-value
Lower 95% CI
Upper 95% CI




4.8
0.0285
0.0174
0.2826













p-value: If the p-value is less than 0.05, we conclude the difference is ‚ÄúStatistically Significant.‚Äù
Sample Estimates: R will show you the individual proportions (\(\hat{p}_1\) and \(\hat{p}_2\)).
Confidence Interval: This interval estimates the true difference between the two population percentages.



Lab Task 13:

Open your Quarto document for Lab 13.
Choose two groups from your data and a binary ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù outcome (e.g., ‚ÄúPass/Fail‚Äù or ‚ÄúYes/No‚Äù).
Create a Stacked Bar Chart using position = "fill".
Run prop.test() to compare the two groups.
Conclusion: State your p-value and write a one-sentence conclusion. ‚ÄúWe [reject/fail to reject] the null hypothesis and conclude there is [a/no] significant difference in the proportions.‚Äù






When creating stacked bar charts, rely on more than just color. Using high-contrast palettes like scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") helps students with color blindness distinguish between the ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù and ‚ÄúFailure‚Äù sections of your bars.

title: Lab 14: Bootstrapping and Resampling
text:
Understand the concept of Sampling with Replacement.
Use the infer package to create a bootstrap distribution.
Estimate a Confidence Interval without assuming the data is ‚ÄúNormal.‚Äù
Compare Bootstrap results to traditional T-test results.





What if your data is skewed, or you have a very small sample size? Traditional math might fail you. Bootstrapping solves this by treating your sample like a ‚Äúmini-population.‚Äù We take thousands of samples from our own data to see how much the mean varies.




In R, the infer package makes the logic of bootstrapping very clear. We follow four steps: specify, generate, calculate, and visualize.

# Install and load the infer package
if(!require(infer)) install.packages("infer")
library(tidyverse)
library(infer)

# Let's bootstrap the mean height of Star Wars characters
boot_dist <- starwars |>
  drop_na(height) |>
  specify(response = height) |>              # 1. What variable?
  generate(reps = 1000, type = "bootstrap") |> # 2. Resample 1000 times
  calculate(stat = "mean")                   # 3. Find the mean each time

#| label: tbl-boot-head
#| tbl-cap: "The first six rows of the bootstrap distribution, showing the calculated mean for each simulation replicate."

head(boot_dist) |>
  knitr::kable()




replicate
stat




1
167.7407


2
177.7407


3
163.6914


4
179.1728


5
170.0988


6
172.8025









Instead of a theoretical curve, we look at the actual distribution of our 1,000 ‚Äúfake‚Äù means.

visualize(boot_dist) +
  labs(title = "Bootstrap Distribution of the Mean",
       x = "Sample Mean Height (cm)", 
       y = "Count")







Figure¬†1: Bootstrap distribution of mean heights for Star Wars characters based on 1,000 resamples.









To find a 95% Confidence Interval, we simply look at where the middle 95% of our 1,000 bootstrap means fall.

# 1. Calculate the interval
percentile_ci <- boot_dist |>
  get_confidence_interval(level = 0.95, type = "percentile")

# 2. Present as an accessible table
knitr::kable(
  percentile_ci,
  col.names = c("Lower Bound (2.5%)", "Upper Bound (97.5%)"),
  digits = 2
)



Table¬†1: 95% Confidence Interval for mean height using the Percentile Method (1,000 bootstrap replicates).






Lower Bound (2.5%)
Upper Bound (97.5%)




167.21
181.85













No ‚ÄúNormality‚Äù Required: It works even if your data is weirdly shaped.
Any Statistic: You can bootstrap the mean, the median, the standard deviation, or even the correlation coefficient.
Visual Logic: It helps you see the uncertainty in your estimate.



Lab Task 14:

Pick a numeric variable from your dataset.
Create a histogram of the original data. (Is it skewed?)
Run the infer code above to generate 1,000 bootstrap reps for the Median instead of the mean (stat = "median").
Visualize the bootstrap distribution.
Calculate the 95% Confidence Interval.
Reflection: In your Quarto document, explain in your own words why we ‚Äúsample with replacement‚Äù during bootstrapping.

title: Lab 15: Non-parametric Methods for Hypothesis Testing
text:
Identify when to use Non-parametric tests instead of Parametric tests.
Conduct a Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test (Mann-Whitney U).
Conduct a Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test for paired data.
Understand how ‚ÄúRanking‚Äù data removes the influence of extreme outliers.





‚ÄúParametric‚Äù tests (like the t-test) assume your data follows a specific distribution (the Normal Distribution). Non-parametric tests make no such assumption. They are often called ‚ÄúDistribution-Free‚Äù tests.



Your sample size is very small (n < 30).
Your data is heavily skewed and cannot be fixed.
You have major outliers that you cannot remove.
Your data is Ordinal (e.g., Likert scales: ‚ÄúSatisfied‚Äù, ‚ÄúNeutral‚Äù, ‚ÄúDissatisfied‚Äù).






This is the non-parametric alternative to the Independent Samples t-test (Lab 12). Instead of comparing means, it compares the medians by ranking all the data points from smallest to largest.
Scenario: Are the ‚ÄúMass‚Äù values of Droids and Humans different? (Mass is often heavily skewed by outliers like Jabba the Hutt). ## Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test: Mass by Species
This test compares the distribution of mass between Humans and Droids. We use this non-parametric test because mass in the Star Wars universe is often skewed by very heavy characters (like Jabba the Hutt).

Accessible Logic: The Wilcoxon test doesn‚Äôt compare means; it compares the ranks of the data. If one species tends to have higher ranks than the other, the test will return a significant result.


library(tidyverse)
library(broom)

# 1. Filter and clean the data
comparison_data <- starwars |> 
  filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid")) |>
  drop_na(mass)

# 2. Run the test and save the results
wilcox_results <- wilcox.test(mass ~ species, data = comparison_data)

# 3. Convert results into an accessible table
tidy_wilcox <- tidy(wilcox_results)

knitr::kable(
  tidy_wilcox[, c("statistic", "p.value", "method")],
  col.names = c("W Statistic", "p-value", "Test Method"),
  digits = 4
)



Table¬†1: Results of the Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test comparing mass between Humans and Droids.











W Statistic
p-value
Test Method




23
0.1989
Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction












This is the non-parametric alternative to the Paired t-test. Use this when you have ‚ÄúBefore‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfter‚Äù measurements on the same subjects, but the differences are not normally distributed.
# Example syntax for paired data
# wilcox.test(before_scores, after_scores, paired = TRUE)

# Creating mock 'before' and 'after' data for the example
before <- c(80, 75, 90, 85)
after  <- c(82, 78, 88, 90)

tidy_paired <- broom::tidy(wilcox.test(before, after, paired = TRUE))

knitr::kable(
  tidy_paired[, c("statistic", "p.value", "method")],
  col.names = c("V Statistic", "p-value", "Test Method"),
  digits = 4
)



Table¬†2: Paired Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test results for character performance.











V Statistic
p-value
Test Method




1.5
0.2693
Wilcoxon signed rank test with continuity correction












While non-parametric tests are safer for ‚Äúmessy‚Äù data, they are slightly less powerful than parametric tests when the data is actually normal. This means they are less likely to find a significant difference if one actually exists.


Lab Task 15:

Pick a numeric variable from your dataset that looks very skewed (not bell-shaped).
Create a Boxplot of this variable grouped by a category.
Run a wilcox.test() to compare the two groups.
Run a standard t.test() on the same data.
Compare: In your Quarto document, compare the p-values. Are they similar? Which test do you trust more for this specific data, and why?






If you are presenting data to a stakeholder and you are worried about one or two ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù outliers ruining your average, the Wilcoxon test is your best friend. It treats the outlier as just ‚Äúthe highest rank,‚Äù preventing it from pulling the results in its direction.

title: Lab 15: Non-parametric Methods for Hypothesis Testing
text:
This is the non-parametric alternative to the Paired t-test. Use this when you have ‚ÄúBefore‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfter‚Äù measurements on the same subjects, but the differences are not normally distributed.
# Example syntax for paired data
# wilcox.test(before_scores, after_scores, paired = TRUE)

# Creating mock 'before' and 'after' data for the example
before <- c(80, 75, 90, 85)
after  <- c(82, 78, 88, 90)

tidy_paired <- broom::tidy(wilcox.test(before, after, paired = TRUE))

knitr::kable(
  tidy_paired[, c("statistic", "p.value", "method")],
  col.names = c("V Statistic", "p-value", "Test Method"),
  digits = 4
)

p-value

title: Lab 15: Non-parametric Methods for Hypothesis Testing
text:
While non-parametric tests are safer for ‚Äúmessy‚Äù data, they are slightly less powerful than parametric tests when the data is actually normal. This means they are less likely to find a significant difference if one actually exists.


Lab Task 15:

Pick a numeric variable from your dataset that looks very skewed (not bell-shaped).
Create a Boxplot of this variable grouped by a category.
Run a wilcox.test() to compare the two groups.
Run a standard t.test() on the same data.
Compare: In your Quarto document, compare the p-values. Are they similar? Which test do you trust more for this specific data, and why?

title: Lab 15: Non-parametric Methods for Hypothesis Testing
text: If you are presenting data to a stakeholder and you are worried about one or two ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù outliers ruining your average, the Wilcoxon test is your best friend. It treats the outlier as just ‚Äúthe highest rank,‚Äù preventing it from pulling the results in its direction.

title: Lab 16: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
text:
Understand when to use ANOVA instead of multiple t-tests.
State the Null (\(H_0\)) and Alternative (\(H_a\)) hypotheses for multiple groups.
Conduct a One-Way ANOVA in R.
Perform Post-hoc testing (Tukey‚Äôs HSD) to find exactly where differences lie.





If you have three groups (e.g., Freshman, Sophomores, Juniors) and you want to compare their average GPA, you could run three separate t-tests. However, every time you run a test, there is a 5% chance of being wrong. By the third test, your error rate has ballooned!
ANOVA tests all groups at once, keeping our error rate at 5%.

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All group means are equal (\(\mu_1 = \mu_2 = \mu_3\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_a\)): At least one group mean is different.





With ANOVA, side-by-side boxplots are essential. They allow us to see if the ‚Äúspread‚Äù within groups is smaller than the ‚Äúdistance‚Äù between groups.

library(tidyverse)

# Filter for the most common eye colors to avoid a cluttered plot
eye_data <- starwars |> 
  filter(eye_color %in% c("blue", "brown", "yellow", "orange")) |>
  drop_na(height)

ggplot(eye_data, aes(x = eye_color, y = height, fill = eye_color)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d() + # High contrast, color-blind safe palette
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Height Distribution by Eye Color",
       x = "Eye Color",
       y = "Height (cm)",
       fill = "Eye Color")







Figure¬†1: Distribution of heights across characters with blue, brown, yellow, and orange eyes.









We use the aov() function. Like the t-test, we use the formula numeric_variable ~ categorical_variable.

library(broom)

# 1. Fit the ANOVA model
model <- aov(height ~ eye_color, data = eye_data)

# 2. Tidy the results into an accessible table
tidy_anova <- tidy(model)

# 3. Create a clean table with descriptive headers
knitr::kable(
  tidy_anova,
  col.names = c("Term", "Degrees of Freedom", "Sum of Squares", "Mean Square", "F-statistic", "p-value"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†1: One-way ANOVA results comparing mean heights across eye color groups.














Term
Degrees of Freedom
Sum of Squares
Mean Square
F-statistic
p-value




eye_color
3
2362.679
787.560
0.772
0.515


Residuals
53
54068.900
1020.168
NA
NA











Df: Degrees of freedom.
F value: The ratio of variance between groups to variance within groups. A large F-value usually leads to a small p-value.
Pr(>F): This is your p-value. If it is < 0.05, we reject the Null.






If your ANOVA p-value is significant, you know someone is different, but you don‚Äôt know who. We use Tukey‚Äôs Honest Significant Difference to compare every possible pair.

library(broom)

# 1. Run Tukey's HSD
tukey_results <- TukeyHSD(model)

# 2. Tidy the results into a clean table
# TukeyHSD returns a list, so we tidy the 'eye_color' element
tidy_tukey <- tidy(tukey_results)

# 3. Create the accessible table
knitr::kable(
  tidy_tukey[, c("contrast", "estimate", "conf.low", "conf.high", "adj.p.value")],
  col.names = c("Comparison", "Difference in Means", "Lower 95% CI", "Upper 95% CI", "Adjusted p-value"),
  digits = 3
)

Lab Task 16:

Identify a categorical variable in your data with 3 or more groups (e.g., County, Year, or Category).
Create a Boxplot comparing a numeric variable across these groups.
Run the aov() function and look at the summary().
Conclusion: * If p > 0.05: State that there is no significant difference between any groups.

If p < 0.05: Run TukeyHSD() and identify which specific pairs are actually different.







ANOVA assumes that the ‚Äúspread‚Äù (variance) is roughly the same for all groups. If one boxplot is massive and another is tiny, the math might be unreliable. In those cases, we go back to the Non-parametric methods from Lab 15!

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Part 1: Correlation (\(r\))
Before building a model, we need to know if a linear relationship even exists. The correlation coefficient (\(r\)) ranges from -1 to 1.

1: Perfect positive relationship.
0: No relationship at all.
-1: Perfect negative relationship.

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Part 2: Visualizing the Best Fit Line
text:
Part 2: Visualizing the Best Fit Line
We use geom_smooth(method = "lm") to draw the line that minimizes the distance between all data points (the ‚ÄúOrdinary Least Squares‚Äù method).

ggplot(lbw_data, aes(x = lwt, y = bwt)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "#002147") + # DCC Navy
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red", se = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Predicting Birth Weight based on Mother's Weight",
       x = "Mother's Weight (lbs)",
       y = "Birth Weight (grams)")







Figure¬†1: Regression of Birth Weight on Mother‚Äôs Weight

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Part 3: Building the Model in R
text:
Part 3: Building the Model in R
In R, the ‚ÄúLinear Model‚Äù function is lm(). The syntax is lm(dependent_variable ~ independent_variable).

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Part 4: Making Predictions
Once you have a model, you can plug in a value for \(x\) to predict \(y\). If our model is \(Mass = -100 + 1.2(Height)\), we can predict the mass of a character who is 200cm tall. ## Model Prediction: 150lb Mother
Using our regression model, we can predict the specific birth weight for a baby based on the mother‚Äôs weight.

Accessible Logic: We are plugging 150 into our regression equation (\(y = mx + b\)). The predict() function calculates this value for us automatically using the model we previously fitted.


# 1. Create a data frame for the input (required by the predict function)
new_mom <- data.frame(lwt = 150)

# 2. Run the prediction
prediction_val <- predict(lbw_model, newdata = new_mom)

# 3. Present the result in a clear, single-row table
prediction_table <- data.frame(
  input_lwt = 150,
  predicted_bwt = prediction_val
)

knitr::kable(
  prediction_table,
  col.names = c("Mother's Weight (lbs)", "Predicted Birth Weight (g)"),
  digits = 2
)



Table¬†5: Predicted Birth Weight for a mother weighing 150 lbs.






Mother‚Äôs Weight (lbs)
Predicted Birth Weight (g)

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Correlation Analysis: Mother‚Äôs Weight vs.¬†Birth Weight
text:
Correlation Analysis: Mother‚Äôs Weight vs.¬†Birth Weight
We are calculating Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficient to see if there is a linear relationship between the mother‚Äôs weight at the last menstrual period (lwt) and the baby‚Äôs birth weight (bwt).

Accessible Logic: Correlation (\(r\)) ranges from -1 to +1. A value of 0 means no linear relationship, while values closer to +1 or -1 indicate stronger relationships.


library(tidyverse)

# 1. Calculate the correlation
cor_result <- lbw_data |>
  drop_na(lwt, bwt) |>
  summarize(correlation = cor(lwt, bwt))

# 2. Display as an accessible table
knitr::kable(
  cor_result,
  col.names = c("Correlation Coefficient (r)"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†3: Pearson Correlation Coefficient between Mother‚Äôs Weight and Birth Weight.






Correlation Coefficient (r)




0.186

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Simple Linear Regression: Predicting Birth Weight
text:
Simple Linear Regression: Predicting Birth Weight
We are fitting a linear model to see how well Mother‚Äôs Weight (lwt) predicts Birth Weight (bwt).

Accessible Logic: We are looking for the equation of a line: \[bwt = \beta_0 + \beta_1(lwt)\]. * The Intercept (\(\beta_0\)) is the predicted birth weight if the mother‚Äôs weight was zero. * The Slope (\(\beta_1\)) tells us how many grams the birth weight increases for every 1-pound increase in mother‚Äôs weight.


library(broom)

# 1. Fit the model
lbw_model <- lm(bwt ~ lwt, data = lbw_data)

# 2. Tidy the coefficients into an accessible table
model_stats <- tidy(lbw_model)

knitr::kable(
  model_stats,
  col.names = c("Term", "Estimate", "Std. Error", "t-statistic", "p-value"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†4: Regression coefficients for predicting Birth Weight from Mother‚Äôs Weight.






Term
Estimate
Std. Error
t-statistic
p-value




(Intercept)
2369.184
228.467
10.370
0.00


lwt
4.430
1.713
2.586
0.01










How to interpret the summary:

Intercept (\(\beta_0\)): The predicted value of \(y\) when \(x\) is zero.
Slope (\(\beta_1\)): For every 1 unit increase in \(x\), how much \(y\) is expected to change.
R-squared (\(R^2\)): The percentage of variation in \(y\) explained by your model. (e.g., \(0.75\) means your model explains 75% of the data).

title: Lab 2: RStudio Projects and Quarto Documents
section: The Three Parts of a Quarto Document
text:
The Three Parts of a Quarto Document
A Quarto document is made of three distinct components:

1. The YAML Header
Look at the very top of the file. You will see text between two sets of three dashes (---). This is the YAML Header; it contains the ‚Äúmetadata‚Äù or settings for your document.
---
title: "Lab 2"
author: "Your Name"
format: html
editor: visual
---


2. Markdown (Narrative)
The plain white areas of the document are called Markdown. This is where you write your analysis, explain your results, and answer questions. It works like a simplified word processor.

You can make text bold by using **double asterisks**.
You can make text italic by using *single asterisks*.



3. Code Chunks
The gray boxes starting with ```{r} and ending with ``` are called Code Chunks. This is where you put your R code to run calculations or create graphs.

# This is a code chunk. R code goes here!
1 + 1

[1] 2








NoteTip for Students



To run the code inside a chunk, click the green Play button in the top-right corner of the gray box. The result will appear directly below the chunk!
crumbs: Lab 2: RStudio Project and Quarto Documents

title: Lab 2: RStudio Projects and Quarto Documents
text:
Part 3: Rendering (The ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù Button)
To turn your code into a report:

Click the Render button (blue arrow icon) at the top of the editor.
RStudio will save the file and pop up a beautiful HTML window.








Importantüìù Lab Task 2: Your First Calculation



Follow these steps to practice using Quarto:

Create a Document: In RStudio, go to File > New File > Quarto Document. Name it Lab2_yourname.
Clean the Workspace: Find the heading that says Quarto. Delete all the example text and code below that line so you have a blank white space.
Add a Title: In that new blank area, type a title for your work: # Lab 2. (Note: Using the # symbol makes the text large like a heading!)
Insert a Chunk: Click the +C button to create a new gray R chunk. Inside the chunk, type: 2 + 2
Render the Report: Click the Render button (blue arrow icon) at the top of your screen.
Check Results: Look at your final HTML report. You should see your title Lab 2, the code 2 + 2, and the result 4.
Submit: upload your HTML report in Brightspace and submit it.
crumbs: Lab 2: RStudio Project and Quarto Documents

title: Lab 3: Mathematical Notation in Quarto
text:
Distinguish between Inline and Display math modes in Quarto.
Use LaTeX syntax to write essential statistical symbols (\(\mu, \sigma, \bar{x}\)).
Format complex equations like Linear Regression for professional lab reports.





In Data Science, we often need to document the mathematical models we use. Quarto uses a system called LaTeX (pronounced ‚ÄúLay-tek‚Äù) to render math. This ensures your formulas look professional and are accessible to screen readers.




There are two ways to display math in your Quarto documents depending on where you want the formula to appear.


Use a single dollar sign $ ... $ when the math should stay inside a sentence.

Code: The population mean is represented by $\mu$.
Result: The population mean is represented by \(\mu\).




Use double dollar signs $$...$$ to center the formula on its own line.

Code: $$\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n}$$
Result: \[\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n}\]






Copy and paste these codes into your Quarto document to practice:



Statistical Term
LaTeX Code
Rendered Result




Sample Mean
$\bar{x}$
\(\bar{x}\)


Standard Deviation
$\sigma$
\(\sigma\)


Summation
$\sum$
\(\sum\)


Correlation Coefficient
$r$
\(r\)


Coefficient of Determination
$R^2$
\(R^2\)







For Linear Regression, we combine several symbols. Try typing this in your Quarto file:
Code: $$y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon$$
Result: \[y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon\]


Lab Task 3:

Open your MAT186_Labs project in RStudio.
Create a new Quarto document (.qmd) titled ‚ÄúMath Practice.‚Äù
Write the formula for the Standard Deviation exactly as shown below: $$s = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}}$$
Render the document to HTML and confirm the formula appears correctly.







Spaces: Do not put a space between the $ and your math code.

Bad: $ \mu $
Good: $\mu$

Missing Signs: If your formula looks like plain text, check if you forgot the closing $.




When you use this LaTeX method, students using screen readers can hear the math described clearly (e.g., ‚Äúx bar equals fraction sum x sub i over n‚Äù). This is much better than using an image of an equation, which a screen reader cannot ‚Äúsee.‚Äù

text:
Welcome to the official lab manual for Introduction to Data Science. This manual will guide you through 17 labs, transitioning from basic data entry to advanced predictive modeling using R and Quarto.






ImportantNew to the Course?

A laptop or tablet is required for all lab sessions.



An account on Posit Cloud or RStudio Desktop installed.

title: Glossary of Data Science Terms
text:
Glossary of Data Science Terms
This glossary provides definitions for key terms used throughout MAT 186. If you encounter a term you don‚Äôt understand in the labs, check here first.


C
CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network): The global network of servers that stores and distributes R and its packages. Think of it as the ‚ÄúApp Store‚Äù for R.


D
Data Frame: A table-like structure in R where each column represents a variable and each row represents an observation.


I
IDE (Integrated Development Environment): A software application (like RStudio) that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development.


M
Markdown: A lightweight markup language with plain-text-formatting syntax. It allows you to write formatted text that can be easily converted to HTML.


Q
Quarto: The next-generation version of RMarkdown. It is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system used to create documents, books, and websites.


Y
YAML: Stands for ‚ÄúYet Another Markup Language.‚Äù In Quarto, the YAML header (at the top of the file) is where you define settings like the title, author, and output format.

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Data Acquisition: Birth Weight Dataset (lbw.csv)
To complete the regression exercises, you need the lbw.csv dataset. Choose one of the methods below to load the data into R.

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Option 1: Direct Link (Recommended)
This method pulls the data directly from the lab manual website. ## Data Loading and Preview
We are using the lbw dataset, which contains information on low birth weight.

Accessible Logic: We use the read_csv() function to pull data from a web URL. After loading, it is important to check the ‚Äúhead‚Äù (the first 6 rows) to ensure the columns and values imported correctly.


library(tidyverse)

url <- url <- "https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/COUNT/lbw.csv"
lbw_data <- read_csv(url)

# 2. Display an accessible preview

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Part 1: Correlation (\(r\))
Before building a model, we need to know if a linear relationship even exists. The correlation coefficient (\(r\)) ranges from -1 to 1.

1: Perfect positive relationship.
0: No relationship at all.
-1: Perfect negative relationship.

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Correlation Analysis: Mother‚Äôs Weight vs.¬†Birth Weight
text:
Correlation Analysis: Mother‚Äôs Weight vs.¬†Birth Weight
We are calculating Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficient to see if there is a linear relationship between the mother‚Äôs weight at the last menstrual period (lwt) and the baby‚Äôs birth weight (bwt).

Accessible Logic: Correlation (\(r\)) ranges from -1 to +1. A value of 0 means no linear relationship, while values closer to +1 or -1 indicate stronger relationships.


library(tidyverse)

# 1. Calculate the correlation
cor_result <- lbw_data |>
  drop_na(lwt, bwt) |>
  summarize(correlation = cor(lwt, bwt))

# 2. Display as an accessible table
knitr::kable(
  cor_result,
  col.names = c("Correlation Coefficient (r)"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†3: Pearson Correlation Coefficient between Mother‚Äôs Weight and Birth Weight.






Correlation Coefficient (r)




0.186

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Part 2: Visualizing the Best Fit Line
text:
Part 2: Visualizing the Best Fit Line
We use geom_smooth(method = "lm") to draw the line that minimizes the distance between all data points (the ‚ÄúOrdinary Least Squares‚Äù method).

ggplot(lbw_data, aes(x = lwt, y = bwt)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "#002147") + # DCC Navy
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red", se = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Predicting Birth Weight based on Mother's Weight",
       x = "Mother's Weight (lbs)",
       y = "Birth Weight (grams)")







Figure¬†1: Regression of Birth Weight on Mother‚Äôs Weight

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Part 3: Building the Model in R
text:
Part 3: Building the Model in R
In R, the ‚ÄúLinear Model‚Äù function is lm(). The syntax is lm(dependent_variable ~ independent_variable).

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
section: Simple Linear Regression: Predicting Birth Weight
text:
Simple Linear Regression: Predicting Birth Weight
We are fitting a linear model to see how well Mother‚Äôs Weight (lwt) predicts Birth Weight (bwt).

Accessible Logic: We are looking for the equation of a line: \[bwt = \beta_0 + \beta_1(lwt)\]. * The Intercept (\(\beta_0\)) is the predicted birth weight if the mother‚Äôs weight was zero. * The Slope (\(\beta_1\)) tells us how many grams the birth weight increases for every 1-pound increase in mother‚Äôs weight.


library(broom)

# 1. Fit the model
lbw_model <- lm(bwt ~ lwt, data = lbw_data)

# 2. Tidy the coefficients into an accessible table
model_stats <- tidy(lbw_model)

knitr::kable(
  model_stats,
  col.names = c("Term", "Estimate", "Std. Error", "t-statistic", "p-value"),
  digits = 3
)



Table¬†4: Regression coefficients for predicting Birth Weight from Mother‚Äôs Weight.






Term
Estimate
Std. Error
t-statistic
p-value




(Intercept)
2369.184
228.467
10.370
0.00


lwt
4.430
1.713
2.586
0.01










How to interpret the summary:

Intercept (\(\beta_0\)): The predicted value of \(y\) when \(x\) is zero.
Slope (\(\beta_1\)): For every 1 unit increase in \(x\), how much \(y\) is expected to change.
R-squared (\(R^2\)): The percentage of variation in \(y\) explained by your model. (e.g., \(0.75\) means your model explains 75% of the data).

title: Lab 17: Linear Regression
text:
Part 4: Making Predictions
Once you have a model, you can plug in a value for \(x\) to predict \(y\). If our model is \(Mass = -100 + 1.2(Height)\), we can predict the mass of a character who is 200cm tall. ## Model Prediction: 150lb Mother
Using our regression model, we can predict the specific birth weight for a baby based on the mother‚Äôs weight.

Accessible Logic: We are plugging 150 into our regression equation (\(y = mx + b\)). The predict() function calculates this value for us automatically using the model we previously fitted.


# 1. Create a data frame for the input (required by the predict function)
new_mom <- data.frame(lwt = 150)

# 2. Run the prediction
prediction_val <- predict(lbw_model, newdata = new_mom)

# 3. Present the result in a clear, single-row table
prediction_table <- data.frame(
  input_lwt = 150,
  predicted_bwt = prediction_val
)

knitr::kable(
  prediction_table,
  col.names = c("Mother's Weight (lbs)", "Predicted Birth Weight (g)"),
  digits = 2
)



Table¬†5: Predicted Birth Weight for a mother weighing 150 lbs.






Mother‚Äôs Weight (lbs)
Predicted Birth Weight (g)




150
3033.68










Lab Task 17:

Pick two numeric variables from your dataset that you think are related.
Create a Scatter Plot and add a linear regression line.
Use the cor() function to find the correlation coefficient.
Fit a linear model using lm() and look at the summary().
The Report:

What is the slope of your model?
What is the \(R^2\) value?
Use your model to make one prediction for a value not in your dataset.

title: Lab 4: Creating Your Data Science Portfolio on GitHub
text:
Create a personal GitHub account.
Initialize a new repository for MAT 186 work.
Understand the ‚ÄúCommit‚Äù and ‚ÄúPush‚Äù workflow.
Host a live version of a lab report using GitHub Pages.





Data Science is a collaborative field. GitHub is the industry standard for version control and sharing code. In this lab, you will set up your own ‚Äúportfolio‚Äù‚Äîa place where you can showcase the work you do in this class to future employers or transfer institutions.





Go to GitHub.com.
Sign up for a free account.

Tip: Choose a professional username (e.g., jsmith-dcc), as you may show this to employers later!

Verify your email address.





A Repository (or ‚ÄúRepo‚Äù) is like a project folder that lives in the cloud.

Click the + icon in the top right and select New repository.
Repository name: mat186-work
Description: ‚ÄúLabs and projects for Introduction to Data Science at DCC.‚Äù
Public/Private: Select Public.
Check the box that says Add a README file.
Click Create repository.





Now, let‚Äôs add the work you‚Äôve done in previous labs.

In your new mat186-work repository, click Add file > Upload files.
Drag and drop your HTML files from Lab 2 and Lab 3 into the browser.
At the bottom, type a ‚ÄúCommit message‚Äù like: Initial upload of Lab 2 and 3.
Click Commit changes.





Let‚Äôs make your lab reports viewable as actual websites.

Go to your repository Settings tab.
On the left menu, click Pages.
Under Build and deployment, set the Branch to main and click Save.
After a minute, GitHub will give you a URL (e.g., https://username.github.io/mat186-work/).

title: üìã Lab Submission Guide
text:
To earn full credit, your lab must be submitted correctly to both GitHub and Brightspace. Use this page as your final checklist!











Section
The Goal
Points




Does it Run?
Your Render button works. There are no red error messages in your final HTML.
5 pts


The Story
You wrote 1-2 sentences under each graph/table explaining what the data shows.
3 pts


The Details
Your name is in the YAML, files are named correctly, and graphs have titles.
2 pts







Professional data scientists make sure their work is readable by everyone!

Human Labels: Rename axis labels (like lwt) to real words (like ‚ÄúMother‚Äôs Weight‚Äù).
Graph Titles: Every visualization needs a clear, descriptive title.
Captions: Use #| fig-cap: "Description" inside your R code chunks.
Clean Tables: Use knitr::kable() to format your data nicely.







Before uploading, ensure your files follow this format:
Lab#_FirstName_LastName
Example: Lab2_Jane_Doe.qmd and Lab2_Jane_Doe.html




Go to your GitHub repository.
Click Add file > Upload files.
Drag BOTH the .qmd and the .html files into the box.
Important: Scroll down and click the green Commit changes button.





Go to the Lab folder in Brightspace.
Upload ONLY the .html file. (This is the file I will grade).







Importantüõë If your code won‚Äôt ‚ÄúRender‚Äù



If you have a code error you can‚Äôt fix: 1. Put a # at the start of the broken line (e.g., # ggplot(...)). 2. This ‚Äúcomments out‚Äù the code so the rest of the document can finish. 3. You might lose a technical point, but you can still earn points for the rest of your work!
